<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">ATS4333</span> - Issues in politics, governance and research<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 1, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ATS4333">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-politics-and-international-relations.html">Politics and International Relations</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Matteo Bonotti">Dr Matteo Bonotti</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Matteo Bonotti">Dr Matteo Bonotti</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ATS4333&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ATS4333">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This is an Honours unit that reflects on research ethics and methods in political studies, and then investigates some of the core issues in debates about governance including the capacity of executive power to make effective policy, the role of the legislature, how interests may be mediated, and what challenges confront supranational governance.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/politics">Politics</a></p>
</div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">ATS3279</span> - Reading and critiquing the European canon today<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ATS3279">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-literary-studies.html">Literary Studies</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Christiane Weller">Dr Christiane Weller</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Christiane Weller">Dr Christiane Weller</a>
<br/>
</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ATS3279">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p>Not offered in 2019</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Twelve credit points of second-year Arts units.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>The unit explores canonical works of European literature, by authors such as Dante, Cervantes, Goethe, and Zola. The unit offers an opportunity to understand different cultures and genres through the study of major literary texts that have had an ongoing influence on the development of national and world literatures. As well as examining and critiquing why these works have been celebrated as "Great Books", the unit critically evaluates the notion of literary canonicity and explores both traditional and subversive approaches to reading them in the twenty-first century.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of the unit, students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>analyse critically a variety of literary texts to evaluate and formulate coherent, sophisticated arguments, both written and oral;</li>
<li>communicate effectively their ideas during in-class discussions based on thoughtful reflection on the issue;</li>
<li>demonstrate a critical understanding of current theoretical approaches to the analysis of canonical literary texts;</li>
<li>exhibit cross-cultural competence through transnational readings of the set texts;</li>
<li>develop research skills pertaining to literary criticism and textual analysis.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 70% + Exam: 30%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/literary-studies">Literary studies</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">MKM5955</span> - Marketing and the international consumer<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MKM5955">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-marketing.html">Department of Marketing</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Vicki Janine Little">Dr Vicki Janine Little</a>
        
        (First semester)
      
    <br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Yunus Ali">Associate Professor Md Yunus Ali</a>
        
        (Second semester)
      
    <br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Vicki Janine Little">Dr Vicki Janine Little</a>
        
        (First semester)
      
    <br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Yunus Ali">Associate Professor Md Yunus Ali</a>
        
        (Second semester)
      
    <br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MKM5955&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MKM5955&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MKM5955">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-malaysia.html">Malaysia</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (Evening)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MKF5955.html">MKF5955</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MKS5955.html">MKS5955</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MKZ5955.html">MKZ5955</a></span>.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Marketing is a means by which organisations create value for their stakeholders within pre-determined objectives. Marketing is widely accepted as a means for delivering greater levels of customer satisfaction, profitability, and sustainability within both a tactical and strategic framework. This unit will prepare graduates for the development, implementation and control processes and procedures of strategic marketing management plans for products and services of an organisation.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>facilitate understanding of the conceptual framework of marketing in value creation and its many applications in decision making under various environmental constraints and with an Asia Pacific focus</li>
<li>evaluate market based information, using it to plan and develop marketing strategies</li>
<li>understand the behaviour of consumers and their role in value creation</li>
<li>understand how value is created using elements of the marketing mix strategies</li>
<li>understand the role of brands in value creation</li>
<li>apply strategic planning tools in developing a marketing mindset.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 50% + Examination: 50%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study.  Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>

<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">AZA1329</span> - Journalism 2: Introduction<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-AZA1329">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>

<ul>

<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=AZA1329&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-AZA1329">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-south-africa.html">South Africa</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>ATS1329</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>The unit provides further development of the key practices of research and reporting for news journalism; the social, professional and legal context for journalism production; the technical production and narrative conventions for at least two different media (print, online, radio and/or video); and consideration of factors affecting the optimal choice of medium for reporting.  Students research and produce original news stories to deadline in at least two media, produce a critical evaluation of their own performance and constructive feedback for their peers.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On successful completion of the unit students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Demonstrate an ability to identify and research a news story, conduct interviews and gather appropriate evidence;</li>
<li>Demonstrate an ability to select an advantageous medium for presentation, and report in a clear, concise, factual way using news conventions in at least two media;</li>
<li>Identify and observe key ethical and legal obligations associated with news reporting in the South African and African Context, and reflect critically on their own and others' performance in this regard;</li>
<li>Work independently and collaboratively in learning and production processes, including online forums, to produce news reports;</li>
<li>Demonstrate an ability to set and meet deadlines, and report under pressure;</li>
<li>Demonstrate an awareness of local, national and international people and events relevant to current issues and media issues;</li>
<li>Demonstrate a critical awareness of the capacities, limitations and socio - professional implications of journalistic practices in different media.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/journalism-studies---south-africa">Journalism studies - South Africa</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="content-inner__main">

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">BEX3300</span> - Business and design<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-BEX3300">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Colin Jevons">Associate Professor Colin Jevons</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BEX3300&amp;tpCode=WS-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Winter semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-BEX3300">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Winter semester 2019 (On-campus block of classes)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Students must have completed 96 credit points.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit is a multi-disciplinary unit that aims to build on students' knowledge of business and/or design but with a focus on how students can use decision making frameworks to tackle difficult business and design problems. The unit provides students the opportunity to demonstrate being critical and creative scholars and responsible and effective global citizens, and gain an understanding of multi-disciplinary decision-making in organisations. Students will have the opportunity to address some difficult problems facing society and use frameworks from business and design to solve such a problem. Students will develop and demonstrate their career-readiness in this unit.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>connect design and business learning in a unique confluence of hybrid skills</li>
<li>develop transferable abilities in leadership, collaboration, communication and negotiation</li>
<li>develop reflective and responsible design and business practices</li>
<li>confidently approach complex challenges using design and business tools and mindsets to resolve them</li>
<li>understand the application of design and business skills across a broad range of global, social, economic and personal challenges</li>
<li>nurture a creative, informed, speculative and future-focused approach to problem solving.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_ada"><span class="unitcode">ARC3001</span> - Architecture design studio 5<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 2, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ARC3001">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_ada">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-ada.html">Art, Design and Architecture</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-architecture.html">Department of Architecture</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Markus Jung">Mr Markus Jung</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Markus Jung">Mr Markus Jung</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ARC3001&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ARC3001">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-overseas.html">Overseas</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (<a href="index-bymode-off-campus.html">Off-campus block of classes</a>)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ARC2002.html">ARC2002</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/OHS1000.html">OHS1000</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="notes">
<p class="hbk-heading hdg_6">Notes</p>
<p></p><p>Within this unit students engage in a range of studio design projects which have quota restrictions. For distribution into studio project groups, consideration will be given to student preference forms, academic performance, and previous design studio experiences. Weighted Average Mark (WAM) may be taken into account to ensure there is an even distribution of students in the studio project groups. Studio project group allocation will be decided by the Program Coordinator and Chief Examiner of the unit.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Architecture Design Studio 5 continues to expand and consolidate the conceptual understanding and skill base of preceding design studios.  It continues to elaborate on architectural design as a process of investigation, critical observation, and experiment. It increases the emphasis on design as a synthetic process encompassing a range of complex issues inherent in the production of architecture: material, structure, program, site, history and representation are investigated in their relationship to the production of architectural form.</p>
<p>Architecture Design Studio 5 continues the development of architectural designs through the consolidation of three-dimensional and material testing of ideas. Studies in the unit will maintain a focus on developing design as a visual language and process of cultural production with an emphasis on social and environmental sustainability</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit students will:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Demonstrate a progression to a refined level of competence in architectural design;</li>
<li>Have the ability to critically analyse and successfully respond to the complex range of issues inherent in an architectural design project;</li>
<li>Have developed a sophisticated understanding of how observation, analysis, experiment and critique apply to the architectural design process;</li>
<li>Have acquired an advanced level of competence and consolidation of all presentation skills: verbal, graphic and 3-dimensional;</li>
<li>Understand and be able to apply the rules of occupational health and safety appropriate to the unit of study.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>100% in-semester assessment</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>24 hours a week including 6 contact hours plus 18 hours of independent study, or equivalent.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">ATS2410</span> - Narrative<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ATS2410">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-literary-studies.html">Literary Studies</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=John Hawke">Dr John Hawke</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=John Hawke">Dr John Hawke</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ATS2410&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ATS2410">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Two gateway units in Literary studies, or permission from the unit coordinator.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>ATS3410, AZA2410, AZA3410</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>The unit will investigate story-telling, narrative literature and the role of narrative in a range of cultural contexts. What constitutes narrative? What are its primary features? How does story-telling communicate meaning? How do we construct effective narrative texts? What do we do with narrative? What is the future of narrative? The texts studied are drawn from a variety of genres and countries.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On successfully completing the unit students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Identify and describe different forms of narrative;</li>
<li>Analyse different narrative genres, devices and techniques;</li>
<li>Apply some of the theoretical perspectives developed in literary and cultural studies disciplines for the critical analysis of narrative;</li>
<li>Identify and account for historical perspectives and conventions within which literature and other narrative texts are produced.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/literary-studies">Literary studies</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_ada"><span class="unitcode">CDS2531</span> - Illustration for animation<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-CDS2531">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_ada">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-ada.html">Art, Design and Architecture</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-design.html">Department of Design</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Ned Culic">Mr Ned Culic</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Van Sowerwine">Ms Van Sowerwine</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=CDS2531&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=CDS2531&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-CDS2531">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/CDS1001.html">CDS1001</a></span> or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/COL1001.html">COL1001</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/CDS1002.html">CDS1002</a></span> or by permission, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/OHS1000.html">OHS1000</a></span></p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>VCO2205</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Illustration for Animation explores the role of illustration and related image-making within the animation industry. Students will be exposed to the processes and techniques illustrators use in the production of animatics, the process of turning written narrative into a sequential visual format. Students will become competent in the creation of storyboards, and understand the principles of editing and composition in the construction of an animated narrative.</p>
<p>In this unit students will become familiar with the union of image transition, dialogue, sound effects, music, dissolves, zooms, pans and other production processes used in the construction of animatics. They will also explore character design as a core component of animated story-telling, and how that character is adapted in order to create convincing action, dialogue and emotional expression.</p>
<p>Students will be exposed to the work of leading exponents of the practice, both contemporary and historic, and be able to critically analyse the processes used this work.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Examine the role illustration plays in the animation industry, through the critical analysis of contemporary and historical works;</li>
<li>Create a storyboard to translate written narrative into a sequential visual format;</li>
<li>Construct an animated narrative using the principles of editing and composition;</li>
<li>Employ image transitions, dialogue, sound effects, music, dissolves, zooms, pans and other production processes used in the construction of animatics;</li>
<li>Design characters for animated story-telling and apply principles to evoke emotion, action and dialogue;</li>
<li>Understand and apply the rules of occupational health and safety appropriate to the discipline practice.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>100% in-semester assessment</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>12 hours per week including 3 contact hours plus 9 hours of independent study.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="content-inner__main">

</li>

<a class="breadcrumbs__link" href="https://www.monash.edu/study">Study</a>
<span aria-hidden="true" class="breadcrumbs__divider">|</span>
</li>
<li class="breadcrumbs__item">
<a class="breadcrumbs__link" href="/pubs/2019handbooks/">2019 Handbooks</a>
<span aria-hidden="true" class="breadcrumbs__divider">|</span>
</li>
<li class="breadcrumbs__item breadcrumbs__current"><a class="breadcrumbs__link" href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units">Units</a></li>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_eng"><span class="unitcode">CHE5882</span> - Biomass and biorefineries<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-CHE5882">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_eng">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-eng.html">Engineering</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-chemical-engineering.html">Department of Chemical Engineering</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Mark Banaszak Holl">Professor Mark Banaszak Holl</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Gil Garnier">Professor Gil Garnier</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=CHE5882&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-CHE5882">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (Online)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>CHE5298</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>The unit covers biomass reaction engineering including kinetics, reaction/mass transfer limitations, selectivity, improving reaction rates, and homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis. The role of biotechnology including enzymatic reactions, fermentation, selectivity will also be studied together with common separation liquid and liquid-solid separation processes.</p>
<p>Global concepts relevant to biorefineries will be emphasised including the carbon cycle (micro and macro perspectives), overall sustainability of water, energy, and minimising by-products from biorefineries.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On successful completion of this unit, students will be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>analyse new developments in fundamental aspects of biorefineries</li>
<li>assess and critique new advances and applications for biorefineries from a technical perspective</li>
<li>evaluate and recommend an appropriate biorefining approach for various biomass feedstocks</li>
<li>review and critique recent biorefinery research literature and synthesise the findings and insights</li>
<li>create and analyse experimental data to produce an accurate and detailed report</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Continuous assessment: 60%</p>
<p>Take-home final examination (case study): 40%</p>
<p>Students are required to achieve at least 45% in the total continuous assessment component and at least 45% in the final examination component and an overall mark of 50% to achieve a pass grade in the unit. Students failing to achieve this requirement will be given a maximum of 45% in the unit.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>On-campus enrolments: 2 hours lectures, 3 hours tutorial and 7 hours of private study per week. 8 hours of laboratories during the semester.</p>
<p>Online enrolments: 144 hours of study</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/chemical-engineering">Chemical Engineering</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_it"><span class="unitcode">FIT5197</span> - Modelling for data analysis<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-FIT5197">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_it">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-it.html">Information Technology</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Wray Buntine">Professor Wray Buntine</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=FIT5197&amp;tpCode=MO-TP1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Teaching Period 2</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=FIT5197&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=FIT5197&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-FIT5197">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-monash-online.html">Monash Online</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Teaching Period 2 2019 (Online)</li><li>Teaching Period 5 2019 (Online)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>(<span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT9133.html">FIT9133</a></span> or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT9131.html">FIT9131</a></span>) and <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MAT9004.html">MAT9004</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="notes">
<p class="hbk-heading hdg_6">Notes</p>
<p></p><p>Monash Online offerings are only available to students enrolled in the <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://online.monash.edu/course/graduate-diploma-data-science/?Access_Code=MON-GDDS-SEO2&amp;utm_source=seo2&amp;utm_medium=referral&amp;utm_campaign=MON-GDDS-SEO2">Graduate Diploma in Data Science</a><span class="hbk-print-url">Graduate Diploma in Data Science (<a href="http://online.monash.edu/course/graduate-diploma-data-science/?Access_Code=MON-GDDS-SEO2&amp;utm_source=seo2&amp;utm_medium=referral&amp;utm_campaign=MON-GDDS-SEO2">http://online.monash.edu/course/graduate-diploma-data-science/?Access_Code=MON-GDDS-SEO2&amp;utm_source=seo2&amp;utm_medium=referral&amp;utm_campaign=MON-GDDS-SEO2</a>)</span> via Monash Online.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit explores the statistical modelling foundations that underlie the analytic aspects of Data Science. Motivated by case studies and working through examples, this unit covers the mathematical and statistical basis with an emphasis on using the techniques in practice. It introduces data collection, sampling and quality. It considers analytic tasks such as statistical hypothesis testing and exploratory versus confirmatory analysis. It presents basic probability distributions, random number generation and simulation as well as estimation methods and effects such as maximum likelihood estimators, Monte Carlo estimators, Bayes theorem, bias versus variance and cross validation. Basic information theory and dependence models such as regression and log-linear models are also presented, as well as the role of general modelling such as inference and decision making, and predictive models.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>At the completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>perform exploratory data analysis with descriptive statistics on given datasets;</li>
<li>construct models for inferential statistical analysis;</li>
<li>produce models for predictive statistical analysis;</li>
<li>perform fundamental random sampling, simulation and hypothesis testing for required scenarios;</li>
<li>implement a model for data analysis through programming and scripting;</li>
<li>interpret results for a variety of models.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Monash Online: In-semester assessment: 100%</p>
<p>On-campus: Examination (2 hours): 50%; In-semester assessment: 50%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload equals 144 hours per semester comprising:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="a">
<li>Contact hours for on-campus students:
<ul>
<li>Two hours/week lectures</li>
<li>Two hours/week laboratories</li>
</ul></li>
<li>Contact hours for Monash Online students:
<ul>
<li>Two hours/week online group sessions.</li>
<li>Online students generally do not attend lecture, tutorial and laboratory sessions, however should plan to spend equivalent time working through resources and participating in discussions.</li>
</ul></li>
<li>Additional requirements (all students):
<ul>
<li>A minimum of 8 hours per week of personal study (22 hours per week for Monash online students) for completing lab/tutorial activities, assignments, private study and revision, and for online students, participating in discussions.</li>
</ul></li>
</ol><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">SWM5235</span> - Family violence and professional practice<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-SWM5235">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-social-work.html">Department of Social Work</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Deborah Western">Dr Deborah Western</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Deborah Western">Dr Deborah Western</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=SWM5235&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-SWM5235">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (Online)</li></ul>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>In this unit students will examine professional practice in relation to gendered family violence (FV) and explore the roles and obligations of community and welfare professionals in the prevention of family violence.</p>
<p>Attention will be drawn to contemporary knowledge and theory regarding family violence and the ways in which this knowledge can be applied in practice. Critical reflection and analysis of knowledge, values and practice/skills constitutes an integral component of the unit.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Analyse the gendered drivers (particularly gender inequality) and reinforcing factors associated with family violence and do so from critical, feminist, intersectional and anti-oppressive theoretical positions and practice-based frameworks</li>
<li>Critique the different and additional manifestations and impacts of family violence on diverse individuals and communities including Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, refugee and immigrant women, LGBTIQ+ individuals, and women with disabilities.</li>
<li>Compare emerging family violence/violence against women prevention strategies and initiatives</li>
<li>Apply actions such as awareness-raising, advocacy, and community development in the development of family violence/violence against women prevention strategies.</li>
<li>Critically reflect on personal values, assumptions and professional practice in family violence prevention practice</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Critical reflection 1(1,000 words) (15%)</li>
<li>Case study (3,000 words) (45%) (hurdle)</li>
<li>Critical reflection 2 (1,500 words) (25%)</li>
<li>Online participation (1,000 words) (15%)</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>This is an off-campus unit.</p>
<p>Students are expected to undertake 12 hours of directed learning activities and 12 hours of self-directed learning including private study.</p>
<p>The unit runs for 12 weeks. For a 6 point unit, off-campus students are expected to spend 12 hours per week completing set learning activities outlined on the Moodle site, participating in online discussion groups, undertaking set readings, and engaging in private study. Private study can include reading additional to the set reading, reflective journalling and field notes, completing assignments and research activities.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/social-work">Social work</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_pha"><span class="unitcode">PAC4482</span> - Preparation for practice<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-PAC4482">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_pha">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-pha.html">Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Suzanne Caliph">Dr Suzanne Caliph</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Suzanne Caliph">Dr Suzanne Caliph</a>
        
        (Parkville)
      
    <br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Juman Dujaili">Juman Dujaili</a>
        
        (Malaysia)
      
    <br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=PAC4482&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-PAC4482">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-malaysia.html">Malaysia</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-parkville.html">Parkville</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>PAC3421</p>
<p>PAC3432</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/PAC4441.html">PAC4441</a></span></p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/PAC4451.html">PAC4451</a></span></p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/PAC4472.html">PAC4472</a></span></p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/PAC4462.html">PAC4462</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit builds on the knowledge and skills developed in the BPharm course. This unit is predominantly conducted through group project work to provide the necessary skills for Continued Profession Development, improve oral and written communication and literature search and evaluation skills. It includes an online moderated discussion group to manage complex patient issues and to familiarise students with the teaching and learning approaches utilised in the Monash Intern Training Program. Students will perform a number of tasks which will help with the development and assessment of communication and clinical problem solving skills, critical thinking skills and develop their skills in decision-making and case-presentation.</p>
<p>The unit comprises three activities:</p>
<ul>
<li>Activity 1: Literature review assignment. This will include a literature review and presentation of assigned pharmacy research related topics completed in small groups.</li>
<li>Activity 2: Complex patient care. This will consist of 3 blocks ofone week moderated discussion groups</li>
<li>Activity 3: Integrated Objective Structured Clinical Examination (OSCE)</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>At the end of this unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Retrieve and evaluate information on a range of pharmacy research related topics and present information in a coherent manner in both written and oral forms;</li>
<li>Communicate effectively to peers and work in a team to achieve a common goal;</li>
<li>Identify and analyse therapeutic management problems in complex patients with multiple disease states and determine appropriate monitoring regimens and management options that demonstrate the principles of evidence-based practice and quality use of medicines;</li>
<li>Formulate an appropriate management plan for a patient based on the use of drug and non-drug therapies;</li>
<li>Recognise when referral for medical assessment is required with a particular emphasis on cardinal symptoms;</li>
<li>Communicate effectively with patients, carers and health professionals to identify drug therapy or illnesses or disease state management problems and recommend appropriate management options and resolutions of those problems</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Activity 1: Literature Review Assignment 20%</p>
<p>Activity 2: Complex patient discussion group 10%</p>
<p>Activity 3: Integrated Objective Structured Clinical Examination (OSCE - Oral examination) 40% (Hurdle - minimum 75% is required to pass this assessment)</p>
<p>Final Written Examination 30%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Contact hours for on-campus students:</p>
<ul>
<li>Four 1-hour workshops</li>
<li>One 2-hour workshop</li>
</ul>
<p>Additional requirements:</p>
<ul>
<li>Three weeks of moderated online discussion groups (approximately 3-4hours/week)</li>
<li>Forty hours group project work including a written report and an oral presentation</li>
<li>Six hours group presentations</li>
</ul><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Additional information on this unit is available from the faculty at:</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="http://www.monash.edu/pharm/current/">http://www.monash.edu/pharm/current/</a> </p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">ACF3600</span> - Auditing and assurance<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ACF3600">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>

<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ACF3600&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ACF3600&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>

</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ACF3600&amp;tpCode=TRI-B-29&amp;tpYear=2019">Trimester B</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ACF3600&amp;tpCode=TRI-C-29&amp;tpYear=2019">Trimester C</a>
</li>

</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ACF3600">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-city-melbourne.html">City (Melbourne)</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Trimester A 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Trimester B 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Trimester C 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ACF2100.html">ACF2100</a></span> or equivalent.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ACB3041.html">ACB3041</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ACW3041.html">ACW3041</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ACC3600.html">ACC3600</a></span>.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit encompasses the nature and purpose of audit and assurance services, and the regulatory and professional environment in which they operate. Students apply professional, ethical and legal requirements stemming from the assurance framework and applicable auditing pronouncements to 'real world' scenarios.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>critically evaluate the demand for and the limitations of audit and assurance services</li>
<li>explain the regulatory ethical and professional requirements applicable to assurance services</li>
<li>understand the assurance framework and apply judgement to determine audit strategy and procedures, appropriateness of evidence gathered and conclusions reached</li>
<li>analyse the auditor's role in corporate governance with emphasis on the detection and reporting of frauds and errors</li>
<li>apply critical thinking, problem solving and communication skills to resolve ethical dilemmas and professional issues faced by audit practitioners.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 50% + Examination: 50%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">MGF2656</span> - HRM and managing global workforces<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MGF2656">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-management.html">Department of Management</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Hannah Meacham">Dr Hannah Meacham</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Hannah Meacham">Dr Hannah Meacham</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MGF2656&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MGF2656">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MGF2661.html">MGF2661</a></span> or equivalent.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit explores the HRM theory and practice of managing workforces globally. Topics may include workforce planning in a global context, design of work processes and systems, and risk management in a dynamic environment.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>explain and critically evaluate the major challenges impacting on workforce planning in organisations</li>
<li>integrate theoretical and empirical knowledge with practical examples</li>
<li>evaluate and recommend human resource management solutions to global workforce challenges.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 60% + Examination: 40%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study.  Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">BFF5977</span> - Risk financing and treasury management<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-BFF5977">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-banking-and-finance.html">Department of Banking and Finance</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Amanda Nguyen">Ms Amanda Nguyen</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Tony Cusack">Mr Tony Cusack</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BFF5977&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BFF5977&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-BFF5977">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Topics include the evaluation of risk; financing tools; retention and transfer; insurance; non insurance; pre and post loss funding; retention and self insurance decisions; insurance and reinsurance principles and practices for the corporate buyer; deductible selection models; management and administration of losses and insurance claims; institutional factors, accounting factors, including taxation and government incentives; captive insurance companies; international considerations; financial transfer by contract.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>develop critical skills in understanding, analysing and applying concepts and models relating to risk management  by the treasury  of  an organisation</li>
<li>develop an understanding  of  optimum  capital structure, maximisation of firm value and investment risk management faced by the treasury</li>
<li>explain the link between theory of derivative  products, insurance products and credit derivatives such as securitisation and the real world situation</li>
<li>develop writing and presentation skills by requiring the submission of group assignments relating to existing practices followed by the banks</li>
<li>develop the ability to work independently  by requiring presentation of tutorials answers relating to risk management by the financial institutions</li>
<li>demonstrate in an individual summative assessment task the acquisition of a comprehensive understanding of the topics covered by BFF5977.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 50% + Examination: 50%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study.  Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_sci"><span class="unitcode">EAE3532</span> - Physics of the solid earth<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-EAE3532">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_sci">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-sci.html">Science</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-earth-atmosphere-and-environment.html">School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Fabio Capitanio">Dr Fabio Capitanio</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Fabio Capitanio">Dr Fabio Capitanio</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=EAE3532&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-EAE3532">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>12 points at level two in EAE, ESC, ENG, PHS or MTH units</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>ESC3332</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit covers the planetary scale structure and dynamics of the Earth, and the fundamental processes which create 'geology' as a natural consequence of Earth evolution. The unit will provide an understanding of the subtle interplay between Earth structure, planetary cooling, geomagnetism, mantle convection, plate tectonics, continental drift, heat flow, earthquakes, melt generation etc, and the diverse measurements/ models needed to gain this understanding including seismicity, seismic tomography, gravity, changing sea level, post-glacial rebound etc. It will concentrate on an integrated, quantitative, model-based approach to the geosciences.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On completion of this unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Describe how the cooling of the earth leads to internal convection.</li>
<li>Describe how a mobile surface and horizontal stresses arise from convective motion.</li>
<li>Visualise plate tectonics as an emergent phenomenon.</li>
<li>Describe the basic principles of plate tectonic reconstruction.</li>
<li>Describe how plate tectonics influences the rotation of the Earth and can change the global climate.</li>
<li>Identify from surface observations how the tectonic stresses are balanced in different geological settings.</li>
<li>Interpret maps of global gravity, stress, earthquake distribution, topography / bathymetry and the underlying mantle structure through seismic tomography.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Practicals: 20%</p>
<p>Assignment: 20%</p>
<p>Examination (2 hours): 60% (Hurdle)</p>
<p>Students must pass the theory examination to achieve an overall pass grade. Students who do not pass the theory examination will receive a mark of  48% unless their aggregate mark is lower</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Two 1-hour lectures and one 3-hour practical per week</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/earth-science">Earth science</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">MGF5920</span> - Work and employment relations<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MGF5920">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-management.html">Department of Management</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Marjorie Jerrard">Dr Marjorie Jerrard</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Marjorie Jerrard">Dr Marjorie Jerrard</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MGF5920&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MGF5920">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (<a href="index-bymode-off-campus.html">Off-campus</a>)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (Evening)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Students must be enrolled in course B4001, B5001, B5002, B6006, B6007, B6009 or B6012.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit provides an introduction to the study of work and employment relations in a changing and dynamic environment. The unit aims to provide students with an understanding of the conceptual foundations of employment relations, the key elements of an industrial relations system, and the dynamics of employment relations in the Australian context. Topics covered include: the individual and the employment relationship, the structure and dynamic of labour markets, the management of employment relations in different industry and workplace contexts, the organisation of work, bargaining and conflict, the role of unions, institutions and the relation of employment relations, and the economic and social consequences of different national systems of employment relations.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>examine the conceptual foundations of work and employment relations</li>
<li>apply these concepts to developments within the Australian system of employment relations in comparative context</li>
<li>describe the main institutional features and key developments in the Australian industrial and workplace relations system</li>
<li>identify the implications of these developments for labour management practices, employee voice and participation in the workplace and representative organisations of employers and employees</li>
<li>understand the potential effects of institutions governing work and employment relations using workplace and industry case studies.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 40% + Examination: 60%</p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>
